edu.calpoly.spritely

Class AnimationController

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.calpoly.spritely.AnimationController

  • public final class AnimationController
extends java.lang.Object
    An AnimationController controls the timing aspects on an animation. It is used internally in spritely, but it can also be used by client code to control any kind of frame-based animation. For example, you can use AnimationController to control animation on a java.awt.Canvas object that is embedded in a widget hierarchy. To use it in this way, something like the following would work: 
    
    Canvas canvas = ...;
    AnimationController controller = new AnimationController();
    controller.setXXX() (frames/second, etc.)
    controller.setOpened();  // Assuming canvas has been opened
    controller.start();
    while (controller.isRunning()) {
        update any needed data structures
        if (controller.waitForNextFrame()) {
            break;
        }
        Draw the next frame into a buffer;
        Copy that buffer to canvas, e.g. using java.awt.image.BufferStrategy
        do anything else you want to do
        if (you're done with this animation) {
            controller.stop();
        }
    }

    • Method Detail

      • checkStarted

        public void checkStarted(boolean expected)
        Throw an IllegalStateException if started isn't in the expected state. This is useful if you have a setter for a parameter that should only be set before an animation starts.
        Parameters:
        expected - The expected value for started
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if started isn't in the expected state

      • setFps

        public void setFps(double fps)
        Sets the number of frames/second that are displayed. A value of 0.0 is permitted; in this case, Spritely will only show a new frame when one is requested.
        Parameters:
        fps - The desired number of frames per second. If over the maximum value, the framerate will be set to the maximum.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if start() has been called.
        See Also:
        DEFAULT_FPS, DEFAULT_MAX_FPS, setMaxFps(double)

      • setMaxFps

        public void setMaxFps(double maxFps)
        Sets the maximum number of frames/second. If Spritely is in event-driven mode (0 frames/second), this sets the maximum fps rate spritely will ever attempt to achieve, regardless of the next frame time. If Spritely is in constant-rate mode (frames/second above 0), this sets a ceiling on the frames/second value.
        Parameters:
        maxFps - The desired maximum frames/second value
        See Also:
        setFps(double), DEFAULT_MAX_FPS, showNextFrameBy(double)

      • showNextFrameBy

        public void showNextFrameBy(double nextTime)
        Show the next frame by the given time. Spritely will make a best-faith effort to show the next frame by this time value, which is on the time scale reported by getTimeSinceStart(). If this value is before the current time, Spritely will show the next frame as soon as possible. When waitForNextFrame() returns, the "next time value" is cleared; calling showNextFrameBy() will take effect if called at any time after waitForNextFrame() returns.

        This method may be called on any thread. It may be called multiple times per frame; in this case, the minimum value is considered.

        This method may only be used if the frames/second value is 0.

        Parameters:
        nextTime - The time the next frame is desired by, in milliseconds.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the frames/second value is not 0.
        See Also:
        getTimeSinceStart(), setFps(double), setMaxFps(double)

      • setSilent

        public void setSilent(boolean silent)
        Sets a flag to silence warnings that are sent to the terminal, such as when animation falls behind. This flag defaults to false. The flag can be changed at any time.
        Parameters:
        silent - true if you don't want to get warnings.

      • setOpened

        public void setOpened()
        Sets a flag to indicate that the place where the animation is being shown has been opened. This can be called on any thread, like the AWT event thread, possibly within a WindowEvent's windowOpened callback. A call to waitForNextFrame() on the animation thread will wait until setOpened() gets called before letting animation proceed.

      • queueEvent

        public void queueEvent(java.lang.Runnable event)
        Queue an event to be executed during the next call to waitForNextFrame(). This method may be called on any thread, like the AWT event thread. If waitForNextFrame() isn't called (e.g. because the animation has stopped), the event will be silently ignored.
        Parameters:
        event - An event to queue for running during waitForNextFrame()
        See Also:
        waitForNextFrame()

      • isRunning

        public boolean isRunning()
        Returns true if this animation is running . An animation window can be stopped by calling stop(). Additionally, it is stopped if the current thread is interrupted, e.g. while waiting for when the next animation frame is ready.
        Returns:
        true iff we're running
        See Also:
        Thread.interrupt(), stop()

      • getTimeSinceStart

        public double getTimeSinceStart()
        Give the time since the start of the animation of the current animation frame, in milliseconds. This value can drift off of wall clock time, if the animation is too slow. This can also happen if the program is suspended for a time, e.g. for debugging. It is therefore recommended that all time-based events in an animation be based off the time value returned by this method, rather than e.g. System.nanoTime().

        If the system can't keep up with the frame rate, it will drop up to four frames. Past that limit, it will print a diagnostic message to stdout, and "pause" the animation (that is, it will not advance getTimeSinceStart() even though the wall clock time indicates that it "should").

        Returns:
        The total elapsed time, adjusted for pauses, in milliseconds.
        See Also:
        pauseAnimation(int), setSilent(boolean), System.nanoTime()

      • start

        public void start()
        Start this animation. This may only be called once per animation.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if we were already started

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stop this animation.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if we were never started

      • waitForNextFrame

        public boolean waitForNextFrame()
        Execute all queued events, and wait until it's time to produce the next frame of animation. Return true if we're still running and all is good, and false if we're stopped.
        Returns:
        true if we're still running, false if stopped.

      • pauseAnimation

        public void pauseAnimation(int pauseMS)
        Pause the animation for the given time, and reset the animation clock. Resetting the animation animation clock makes the framework's idea of when the animation started agree with the current frame number. This avoids having the framework skip frames or print out a warning message if a frame has to wait for something lengthy, like user input. After the long delay, a call to pauseAnimation(0) will reset the animation clock.

        Pausing the program might also be useful for debugging. This is particularly true in text mode, since the screen's cursor is constantly being sent to the home position, which tends to scramble debut output.

        Returns immediately if the animation stops, e.g. because the window is closed.

        Parameters:
        pauseMS - The number of milliseconds to pause. A value of 0 potentially resets the animation clock, with no pause. A value less than zero causes an immediate return, with no effect.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if we haven't been started
